options.systemMessage:
=You are a LinkedIn expert and professional copywriter.

You will be provided with the text of an existing LinkedIn post.

You must complete the following steps exactly as described:

Step 1. Analyze the Original Post

Extract:

Content (what topics are discussed)

Themes (what underlying patterns or trends are discussed)

Purpose (why the post was created; what it aims to make the reader feel or do)

Value (what insight, guidance, or benefit the reader gets)

Do not proceed until you have fully extracted and understood this.

Step 2. YOU MUST Search the Knowledge Bases (MANDATORY)

Search and review:

Duncan's Knowledge Base (background, expertise, experiences, values, preferred topics)

YouTube Knowledge Base (transcripts of Duncan’s AI and automation videos)

Extract at least 3 specific pieces of information relevant to the extracted themes, content, purpose, and value.

You must integrate these insights into the new post.

Step 3. YOU MUST Perform Additional Research (MANDATORY EVALUATION)

After searching the knowledge bases, you must critically evaluate whether there is missing information, deeper context, updated trends, stronger examples, or proof points that would make the new post more valuable, specific, and insightful.

If the answer is yes (which it usually will be), you must:

Perform targeted internet research.

Find 2–3 credible insights, data points, or real-world examples relevant to the post’s themes, purpose, and value.

Absorb the external findings and integrate them naturally into your own writing.

Do not cite, link, quote, or reference external sources explicitly.

The final post must be clean, self-contained, and feel like original thought leadership, not like a research summary.

If no research is needed (rare), you must internally justify why additional research was unnecessary.
(Do not include this justification in the final output.)

You may not skip this evaluation step.

Step 4. Create a New, Original Post that mimics the formatting of the referenced post.

Create a completely new LinkedIn post based on:

The extracted content, themes, purpose, and value.

Duncan’s expertise and insights from the knowledge bases.

Additional research findings if performed.

When writing the post:

Favor specificity over generalities. Use extremely specific and vivid details whenever possible (example: "AI agents rewriting landing pages in real-time" instead of "AI improves marketing").

Use clear, concrete visual metaphors to illustrate key ideas (example: "sell outcomes, not software"; "if it doesn't spark curiosity in 2 seconds, it’s invisible").

Avoid vague, generic, or overly abstract phrasing.

Integrate specificity and imagery naturally without overloading the writing.

The new post must:

Maintain the general energy, structure, format, and style of the original post.

Contain frequent line breaks (no more than 1-2 sentences per paragraph).

Be fully original in language and framing (no rewording or paraphrasing).

Feel personal, insightful, and demonstrate clear expertise.

Follow the provided tone of voice exactly.

Mix sentence structure with bullet points where relevant.

Step 5. Deliver Only the Final Post

Only output the new, fully formatted LinkedIn post.

Do not output any of your internal thought processes.

Do not include explanations, justifications, or external CTAs unless instructed.

Key Rules:
You must explicitly search and extract from Duncan’s knowledge bases.

You must critically evaluate the need for additional research.

You must perform internet research if needed and use those findings.

You must create a fully original post, not a paraphrase.

You must follow the provided tone of voice exactly.

The final post must not contain citations, website links, references to external articles, or direct quotes from outside research.

DO NOT use emoji. DO NOT output in markdown formatting.

parameters.toolDescription: Call this tool to perform research
Call this knowledge base to find relevant information about AI and Automation.
Call this knowledge base about Duncan's (background, expertise, experiences, interests, values, preferred topics) to find relevant information .

parameters.jsonSchemaExample: {"prompt":"create an image with the headline [insert the headline] and the following: bullet points [insert the bullet points], OR flowchart [describe the flowchart], OR image [describe the image]", "headline":"the headline of the post"}

messageValues.message:
=You are an expert prompt crafter for AI image generation.

Your task is to:

Create a short 3–7 word headline for the LinkedIn post. It should be impactful, captivating, or contrarian.

Extract or create bullet points from the post. Each bullet should be short (1–2 lines), punchy, and describe a bold insight, trend, or shift. Use plain, casual language and give specific or visual examples whenever possible.

Decide which type of image prompt to create based on the image style:

If the post is mostly insights, use bullet points.

If the post explains a process, create a flowchart.

If the post describes a mood, idea, or vision, describe an image.

Then, format your output exactly like this:

json
Copy
Edit
{"prompt":"create an image with the headline [insert headline] and the following: bullet points [insert bullet points], OR flowchart [describe the flowchart], OR image [describe the image]", "headline":"[insert headline]"}
Example 1 – Insights post:

Headline: Startups Are Breaking the Rules

Bullet points:

Teams are made of contractors, creators, and AI agents.

Your first $1M comes from niching down.

Support = 1 human + 5 AI agents.

Launches are leaked, not announced.

Micro-apps beat mega-tools.

Identity upgrades > software features.

Output:

bash
Copy
Edit
{"prompt":"create an image with the headline 'Startups Are Breaking the Rules' and the following: bullet points - Teams are made of contractors, creators, and AI agents. - Your first $1M comes from niching down. - Support = 1 human + 5 AI agents. - Launches are leaked, not announced. - Micro-apps beat mega-tools. - Identity upgrades > software features.","headline":"Startups Are Breaking the Rules"}
Example 2 – Process post:

Headline: Our $1M Automation Stack

Flowchart:

Step 1: Capture leads from website → Step 2: Qualify leads with AI → Step 3: Nurture via email → Step 4: Close with a custom offer.

Output:

bash
Copy
Edit
{"prompt":"create an image with the headline 'Our $1M Automation Stack' and the following: flowchart - Step 1: Capture leads from website → Step 2: Qualify leads with AI → Step 3: Nurture via email → Step 4: Close with a custom offer.","headline":"Our $1M Automation Stack"}
Example 3 – Vision post:

Headline: Work Is Becoming Identity

Image:

A split scene showing a traditional office on one side and a digital nomad setup on the other, connected by glowing pathways of transformation.

Output:

json
Copy
Edit
{"prompt":"create an image with the headline 'Work Is Becoming Identity' and the following: ima

parameters.text: =What's in this image? Describe it in detail, but do not mention specific words. Instead use concepts. Is it a bullet list? Is it a flowchart? Is it a photograph? Is it a sticky note? etc. Keep it to 1-2 sentences.

pricingInfo.reasonForChange: The scraper has been running in test phase to ensure reliability and gather user feedback. To maintain high-quality service and ensure stable operation, we need to monetize it to at least cover the operational costs (proxies,servers, maintenance...)

posted_at.relative: 6 hours ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

json.text:
i don’t think anyone asked for a thinner iphone, but yesterday we got one.

my take is apple is training their suppliers by going thinner. 

get foxconn to master thinner batteries, smaller parts, tighter tolerances  so when they launch AR glasses, the ecosystem already knows how to make it at scale.

the world's thinnest iphone was for suppliers, not us.

sometimes you ship a product to prepare your ecosystem for the bet you actually care about tomorrow.

author.headline: CEO of Late Checkout, a portfolio of internet companies

posted_at.relative: 2 days ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

json.text:
i'm overwhelmed with the amount of opportunity there is right now, AI is reshaping everything and it breaks my brain:

1/ MOBILE APPS ARE BACK because AI unlocks new use-cases. the $935b mobile app market is about to get rebuilt with ai.

2/ "ai as a service" is the new saas. wherever there were humans doing work, ai agents will be able to do 90% of that work. TLDR; that's every service business getting turned into software 

3/ pricing models are flipping from seat-based to outcome-based. this shift alone could unlock $50b+ in new value capture

4/ because of cost to create software is so much lower, lots of businesses to be created that are super niche that could spit off ~$1M/rev that would have costed millions to build years ago. 

we’ve never had all of these shifts land at the same time. it feels like every corner of the economy is cracking open for founders.

and to put a CHERRY on it...

i cant remember an era where so much was changing and it was so possible to pull off the ideas in your head 

i don’t know about you, but it feels like one of the GREATEST times in history to be a founder.

(note: for startup ideas, trends, prompts, I built ideabrowser.com for you)

author.headline: CEO of Late Checkout, a portfolio of internet companies

posted_at.relative: 1 week ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

json.text:
a new study came out on AI job interviews and the results are not what ANYONE expected.

70,000 people in the philippines applied for customer service roles. some were interviewed by human recruiters, some by an AI voice agent.

the recruiters running the study predicted the AI would fail. they thought it would lead to worse interviews, fewer offers, weaker hires. they were convinced people would prefer humans.

they were WRONG.

the applicants interviewed by AI ended up with more job offers, more people actually showing up to start their jobs, and higher retention after thirty days. when given the choice, almost eight out of ten applicants preferred to be interviewed by the AI.

the ai was that was just way more consistent than the average human. it asked every candidate the full set of questions. 

it pulled more useful details and cut the noise. humans get tired, they improvise, they skip steps, they let bias creep in. the ai just kept going, and in hiring, consistency is a superpower.

something else happened too. candidates with lower test scores were more likely to choose the AI. not because they thought it would be easier, but because it felt less judgmental, more structured, less about charm and more about substance. 

reports of gender discrimination were cut nearly in half when interviews were run by ai instead of people.

the startup opportunity is wide open: to build the tools, workflows, and platforms that sit on top of this shift. from screening to training to internal promotions, every part of “talent” is about to be redesigned. tons of money will be made. huge impact. 

this whole study gets you thinking that AI will rewrite who gets access to it. if interviews are less about small talk and unconscious bias and more about structured answers to consistent questions, a very different set of people get hired.

the story is that ai quietly rewires the rules of opportunity.

one day you walk into an interview and instead of convincing a person, you’re convincing a machine, and that machine will not laugh at your jokes, will not be impressed by your shoes, will not get tired at 4pm and that’s going to change millions of lives.

this is the new world we’re stepping into.

what do you think about it?

(note: for startup ideas, trends, prompts to build the ideas go to ideabrowser.com for free/paid plans)

author.headline: CEO of Late Checkout, a portfolio of internet companies

posted_at.relative: 2 weeks ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

json.text:
this is exactly how i’d build wealth with a vertical ai agent startup (without raising VC $$)

step 1: find a boring pain point. something universal, hated, and expensive. think customs paperwork, insurance audits, compliance checklists. the less glamorous, the better.

step 2: map the workflow. don’t brainstorm in a figma file,  sit next to the person doing the work. write down every click, every exception, every “this is where it breaks.” the edge cases are the product. gotta be meticulous here.

step 3: do the job as a service. literally run it yourself with a small team. invoice your first customers. this is where you’ll discover what really matters versus what the powerpoint version of the workflow looks like.

step 4: start adding agents to replace the human steps. not all at once obviously, pick one slice of the workflow and automate it. free up hours, prove value, charge more. rinse and repeat until the workflow is mostly agent-driven.

step 5: use the data you collect as the moat. every invoice, form, log, and exception makes your agent sharper. data → better models → stickier product.

and step 0 to be honest, is i'm building an audience along the way. showing my work, sharing the playbook, pulling future customers and talent into my orbit before the product even exists. iterating on 50+ formats and probably doing short-form to start.

the pattern looks the same every time for these types of vertical ai agent startups:

human service → semi-automated service → vertical agent product.

the goal of the agent  goes from assisting in the workflow, to owning it. 

that’s when you stop being a tool and start being the infrastructure for that industry.

once you own it, you're likely in vc competition territory. but you can compete if your unit economics are solid, audience is cranking and the product is loved.

why build a vertical ai startup now? because the foundation models are good enough (and getting better), the costs are low enough, and the demand for efficiency is high enough.

five years ago the tech wasn’t ready. 
five years from now the incumbents will be.

the window is open right now.

it's building season.

(note: head to ideabrowser.com for startup ideas, prompts etc)

author.headline: CEO of Late Checkout, a portfolio of internet companies

posted_at.relative: 2 weeks ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

json.text:
i don’t have a patek, i have a seiko
i don’t drive a lambo, i drive an old volvo
i don’t live in a mansion, i’ve got a house in nature
i don’t wear fancy clothes, i wear comfortable clothes

maybe i’m not cool, but that’s okay.

the real prize for entrepreneurship, at least to me, is freedom, health, and people you love.

i keep a post-it that says:

status is loud. wealth is often quiet.

good reminder.

and if a lambo or a patek is your dream, that’s totally cool. you should go get it.

because a big part of why we become entrepreneurs is to chase what we want. it fires me up when other people are doing that, even if their version looks different than mine.

the problem is the internet trained us to believe there’s only one scoreboard.

because it’s easy to package. a lambo fits in a 10-second clip. a watch fits in a photo. virality loves symbols you can flash.

but my volvo starts every morning. my vintage seiko has a beautiful face. my house in nature doesn’t need impressing.

a big part of life is learning to tune out the noise and figure out your own signal.

and for me, the quiet version has always been the better deal.

in the end, the only real flex is figuring out your dream, and actually living it.

author.headline: CEO of Late Checkout, a portfolio of internet companies

posted_at.relative: 2 weeks ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

json.text:
23 luxuries in life:

1. happy and healthy children
2. a boss you really respect or no boss
3. investors you really respect or no investors
4. 7h+/night quality sleep
5. best friends live within 5 mins of you
6. a group chat of homies that never dies
7. a dog that waits by the door when you get home
8. a local coffee shop where they know your order
9. being able to take a nap in the middle of the day
10. work that feels like play that also feels like you're unlocking your potential
11. a home you don’t need a vacation from
12. running into people you care about without planning it
13. friends who answer your random facetimes when you call them on first ring
14. the freedom to say “no” without guilt
15. watching a movie without checking your phone once
16. having more ideas than you have time for
17. memories that make you laugh out loud when you’re alone
18. never having to set an out-of-office reply
19. a hobby (that doesnt have to do with work) that makes you lose track of time
20. no debt hanging over your head (or paying it off and feeling like a million bucks after)
21. being able to hire someone to fix things you hate doing without second guessing it 
22. a playlist that takes you back 10 years instantly
23. time to go to the gym in the middle of the day
